TopicTitle: I did a quick part heat overload test.

Articles.Content:
I was reading [**THIS**](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/117930-Guide-New-temperature-rules-for-parts-in-1-0-%281-0-2-updates%29) awesome guide, and after looking at the thermal coefficients, and using some things I usually attach rockets to, made a small thermal test to see which these parts exploded first, and which one exploded last.

Images are in order of time.

**LEFT TO RIGHT:** Solar panels radially mounted, large battery, small service bay, large service bay, mk3 monopropellant tank, 1.25 fuel tank.

> ![qkNN8ln.png](http://i.imgur.com/qkNN8ln.png)
> ![v4STS97.png](http://i.imgur.com/v4STS97.png)
> 
> ![z7Es7X6.png](http://i.imgur.com/z7Es7X6.png)
> 
> ![PwirRSt.png](http://i.imgur.com/PwirRSt.png)
> 
> ![UXXrqds.png](http://i.imgur.com/UXXrqds.png)
> 
> ![ess0xeL.png](http://i.imgur.com/ess0xeL.png)
> 
> ![5tw58VY.png](http://i.imgur.com/5tw58VY.png)
> 
> ![0BU8GBS.png](http://i.imgur.com/0BU8GBS.png)

**IN CONCLUSION:** 

\* Radially mounted solar panels over heated first

\* Large battery overheated second

\* Large service bay and 1.25 fuel tank overheated around the same time at third

\* Mk 1.25 service bay overheated second to first

\* Mk3 monoprop tank overheated last

Please comment if you have anything related to thermal temperature tips, and methods to dissipate it. ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)

- Avera9eJoe
